children.subject: Ok, I see. But aren't there other important topics that can also be taught?

1.  Overlap is inevitable.  2.  Also realize that the curriculum was constructed that way so that there are as few pre-req's as possible so everyone can specialize in what they are interested in; otherwise everyone would be forced to take the same linear path.

history.content:
That is indeed true for CS, and is more true as you take more classes in the CS/EE departments. For example, 3/4 of the CS 174 material overlaps with CS70, there's a lot of overlap between 162 and 186 (and 161 and 168). Most of the circuit EE upper-divs overlap with EE40, There's a tremendous amount of overlap between 162 and the embedded systems EE course as well.

I've taken pretty much all of the CS upper divs, and think that this is true because there's simply not much content/material in EECS that don't overlap with each other...

-------------

CS70 doesn't cover graphs in the same way that CS61B or CS170 does. CS170 has been spending less time recent semesters on the parts of graphs that 61B covers, but there are a lot more to graphs that CS170 covers. Graphs are also a very fundamental / important topic, hence why basically there are many other classes that you don't mention that also cover graphs, in increasing depth. There's certainly enough material in the topic of "graphs" for all of those classes, even without overlap.

But EE126 (and also CS174) spend an excessive amount of time reviewing the prereq material from CS70, yes.

That is indeed true for CS, and is more true as you take more classes in the CS/EE departments. For example, 3/4 of the CS 174 material overlaps with CS70, there's a lot of overlap between 162 and 186 (and 161 and 168). Most of the circuit EE upper-divs overlap with EE40, There's a tremendous amount of overlap between 162 and the embedded systems EE course as well.

I've taken pretty much all of the CS upper divs, and think that this is true because there's simply not much content/material in EECS that don't overlap with each other...

For example, 3/4 of the CS 174 material overlaps with CS70, there's a lot of overlap between 162 and 186 (and 161 and 168). Most of the circuit EE upperdivs overlap with EE40, There's a tremendous amount of overlap between 162 and the embedded systems EE course as well.

I've taken pretty much all of the CS upper divs, and think that this is true because there's simply not much content/material in EECS that don't overlap with each other...
This would be a great thing to write about on the undergrad survey @2868

children.subject: Personally I'm very glad that there is overlap. You only build true understanding of material by accessing the material recurrently over time

history.content:
Is this a mistake or am I missing something?

Why not cover things students haven't learned yet?

- Half of CS 61A is trees and linked lists. One third of CS 61B is trees and linked lists.

- CS 70, CS 170, and CS 61B all cover graphs.

- The first third of EE 126 is CS 70 material.
history.subject: Is there too much overlap in CS classes?

history.content:
Is this a mistake or am I missing something?

Why not cover things students haven't learned yet?

- Half of CS 61A is trees and linked lists. One third of CS 61B is trees and linked lists.

- CS 70, CS 170, and CS 61B all cover graphs.

- The first third of EE 126 is CS 70 material.

- Dynamic programing is taught in CS 61B (very little) and CS 170. Why not teach a new data structure in CS 61B instead?
history.subject: Is there too much overlap in CS classes?

history.content:
I've noticed a lot of overlap in Berkeley CS classes. Is this a mistake or am I missing something?

Why not cover things students haven't learned yet?

- CS 70, CS 170, and CS 61B all cover graphs.

- The first third of EE 126 is CS 70 material.

- Dynamic programing is taught in CS 61B (very little) and CS 170. Why not teach a new data structure in CS 61B instead?
